ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Follow That Garbage!, we talked about what happens to garbage after we throw it away. We also saw lots of different shapes, like the wheels on the truck and the windows in the buildings.

In this activity, you will turn over two cards. Say the name of the shape and how you know the shape. If both cards are the same shape, you keep the cards. If it’s not a match, turn them over, and it will be the next friend’s turn to play.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Before beginning the activity, flip through the cards to go over the name of each shape and discuss its features. Point out that even though shapes may be different sizes or colors, they are still the same shape.
Set Up Place Activity Cards face-down on the table. Have children take turns picking and turning over two cards.

Ask What shape is this? How can you tell? Prompt children to identify the features of the shape as needed. This shape has three sides and three corners. It is a tr (triangle). If a child has turned over two of the same shape, the child keeps both cards. If the shapes do not match, guide the child to turn both cards back over.
Repeat Continue the activity until all children have had multiple turns. When all the cards have been matched, shuffle and start over.

Talk About Shapes Talk with children about how shapes can be different sizes and colors. Remind children that they know how to identify shapes based on the number of sides they have, whether the sides are equal, and how many corners they have.

Remove the triangles from the cards so that all the cards show either circles or squares. Once children have each had a chance to match circles and squares, discuss the features of triangles, and add them to the activity.
Show children the cards face up and in position before turning them face down. Before children begin looking for a match, ask them to say what shape they are looking for and to describe the shape.
Remind Spanish speakers of the cognates circle and circulo, and triangle and triangulo. Cognate awareness is a tool to help children understand a second language.

Provide children with triangles, circles, and squares from the Pattern Blocks or other classroom objects to feel and use for reference. Help children connect the physical shapes to the shapes on the cards.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Pattern Blocks for each child.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Follow That Garbage!, we talked about the rules for throwing out garbage. We also talked about the shapes we saw in the book.
In this activity, I will give you a rule, and you will follow that rule when making a picture with the Pattern Blocks. You can make any picture you want, as long as it follows the rule I say.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Give a sample rule such as, “Use two triangles.” Create a picture of a garbage truck using two triangles and a variety of other shapes. Point to the two triangles you used, and explain how you made whatever you wanted but followed the rule.

Ask What can you make that uses a square? You can make whatever picture you want, as long as you use a square. After children have arranged their Pattern Blocks, have them share what they made and point to the square in it.
Repeat Continue with rules about different shapes in the patterns, having children make new pictures each time.

Talk About Shapes Discuss the different shapes in the Pattern Blocks with children. Have them share how they identified which shape to use based on your rule. Challenge children to explain the differences between similar shapes like the diamond and square, for example.

Begin the activity by reviewing the names of the shapes of each Pattern Block and having children repeat them. Discuss the features of each shape and point out the number of sides and corners, and how the points are different.

After the first round, give children two rules to follow at one time, such as needing to use a square and a diamond in their designs. Guide children to name the shapes correctly when sharing their designs.
Review the numbers one to five and the names of shapes to prepare children for the rules you say in the activity. You can also review the word rule and what it means in this context.

To support fine motor development, have children draw images of shapes instead of using Pattern Blocks. Be sure to have children point out the features of each shape, and assure them it is unnecessary to draw it perfectly.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Follow That Garbage!, we talked about the different types of garbage. We also saw shapes that are solid shapes, like cans and boxes, in the garbage.

In this activity, you will turn over two cards. Say the name of the solid shape and how you can tell what it is. If both cards show the same solid shape, it’s a match and you keep the cards. If it’s not a match, turn them over and it will be the next friend’s turn to play.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary We learned the phrase solid shape. Use the solid shape Vocabulary Card to reteach the phrase.

Teach Before beginning the activity, flip through the cards to go over the name of each shape and discuss its features. Point out that even though they may be different objects, they are the same shape. You may also point out that the images are flat, but the real shapes are solid.
Set Up Place Activity Cards face-down on the table. Have children take turns turning over two cards.

Ask What solid shape is this? How can you tell? If a child turned over two of the same shape, guide the child to keep both cards. If the shapes do not match, guide the child to turn both cards back over.
Repeat Continue the activity until all children have had multiple turns. When all the cards have been matched, shuffle and start over.
Talk About Solid Shapes Ask children how they recognized each shape. Discuss other real-world examples of each solid shape besides the ones pictured on each card.
Provide real world objects from the classroom that demonstrate the different solid shapes, and match them up with the same shapes on the cards before beginning.
Have children identify another object that has the same shape as their Activity Cards. Encourage children to describe how they can identify that it is the same shape.
Begin the activity by reviewing the names of the shapes in English. You can also encourage children to name the shapes in their home languages, and then reinforce the English names.
Provide the name of each item pictured before beginning the activity. Support children by prompting them to name the correct shape. For example, This is a block. It is shaped like a b . (box)

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We learned in You Can Help! that recycling is an important thing we can do to protect the Earth. One part of recycling is knowing which items can be recycled, like cans. We also talked about cans and other shapes, like boxes and cones.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary We learned the word recycle. Use the recycle Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.
Explain the Activity In this activity, you will quietly search the classroom for a solid shape. Then you will bring back your example, and we will discuss it.
Review the Shapes Use the Activity Cards from 7.4.3 to review solid shapes and their features.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Can you find a solid shape in the room?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Extend When each child brings back an item, discuss what shape it is and how the child knew what shape it was. Ask why they chose those shapes. Have children compare shapes to see if any of them brought back different items that are the same solid shape.
Repeat If time allows, ask children to seek out new shapes in the classroom and bring them back, and repeat the discussion with the new shapes.

Talk About Recycling Talk about the solid shapes each child brought back. Ask if there are other things that are those shapes and whether or not they can be recycled. Discuss ways to determine whether something can be recycled, like asking an adult or researching it on the Internet with an adult.

If children are having difficulty identifying the shapes they brought back, name the features of one solid shape. Ask children whether the object they brought is that shape. Repeat with the features of the other solid shapes.
Ask children to look for specific shapes in the classroom. You can assign different children different shapes to ensure a variety of shapes to compare and discuss.
Multilingual learners may be able to sort the shapes easily by sight without knowing the names of the shapes. Review the names with children, and encourage them to say them aloud during the activity.

Review with children how to move carefully and quietly when they look for and retrieve objects so that they do not disrupt classmates working on other activities. Model going to an area, getting an object, and bringing it back to the group.
